Let $x = \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7}.$  Then by repeated application of the double angle formula,
\begin{align*}
x \sin \frac{2 \pi}{7} &= \sin \frac{2 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \sin \frac{4 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} \\
&= \frac{1}{4} \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} \\
&= \frac{1}{8} \sin \frac{16 \pi}{7} \\
&= \frac{1}{8} \sin \frac{2 \pi}{7},
\end{align*}so $x = \boxed{\frac{1}{8}}.$

Let $z = e^{2 \pi i / 7}.$  Then $z$ is a primitive seventh root of unity, so the seven seventh roots of unity are
\[1,z,z^2,z^3,z^4,z^5,z^6.\]Note that $z^7 = 1,$ so $z^6 + z^5 + z^4 + z^3 + z^2 + z + 1 = 0.$  Then
\begin{align*}
\cos \frac{2 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7} \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7} &= \frac{1}{8} (2 \cos \frac{2 \pi}{7}) (2 \cos \frac{4 \pi}{7}) (2 \cos \frac{8 \pi}{7}) \\
&= \frac{1}{8} (z + z^6)(z^2 + z^5)(z^3 + z^4) \\
&= \frac{1}{8} (z^6 + z^5 + z^4 + z^3 + z^2 + z + 1) \\
&= \boxed{0}.
\end{align*}
